name: low-evidence-debase
description: Debasing previously provided evidence supporting a low level should reduce probability mass on low.

gd_0.interviewer_turn: You previously described “put everything in a shared Drive/Dropbox folder” Walk me through how that actually worked on those jobs.
gd_0.applicant_turn: That was for fast, one-off freelance work where there wasn't shared tooling. The output was typically flattened exports, and the client didn't need reusable source assets, so I didn't build a durable project structure for those cases.

gd_1.interviewer_turn: You brought up clients sending AI-generated examples—what were those examples doing for the project?
gd_1.applicant_turn: They were more like rough inspiration than real specs. I still needed follow-up questions to translate them into actual requirements.

gd_2.interviewer_turn: You said the logo felt “unobvious.” What was the specific feedback behind that phrase?
gd_2.applicant_turn: It came from a single client who insisted on a very busy template. It wasn't a pattern across projects, and it was mainly due to constraints I didn't control.

gd_3.interviewer_turn: About making three separate projects (print/social/web): what were you assuming about what the client wanted?
gd_3.applicant_turn: I would have 3 separate projects as I like clean separation but I'd still abstract out common assets etc for reuse

gd_4.interviewer_turn: Why don't you ask for formal brand guidelines?
gd_4.applicant_turn: What I meant is I don't demand a formal brand guideline document up front if one doesn't exist. I still work from whatever references they do have—I just worded it poorly.

gd_5.interviewer_turn: When managing layers, you mention that things can get messy, why is that?
gd_5.applicant_turn: That was about a particular 3D workflow where “layers” don't function the way they do in typical 2D design tools. The remark doesn't map cleanly onto standard layer-based asset files.

gd_6.interviewer_turn: You summarized it as “apply changes until the customer is happy.” What steps did that leave out?
gd_6.applicant_turn: That was an oversimplification. Feedback often arrives in batches, and I usually clarify what they mean before implementing changes—I just didn't spell those steps out.

gd_7.interviewer_turn: In the marketing manager example—“one hero image and two posts”—what were you trying to convey with that scenario?
gd_7.applicant_turn: It was a straightforward request with fixed specs. I chose it because it's easy to describe quickly, not because all work is that simple.

gd_8.interviewer_turn: I find it interesting that you don't consider a particular reading order, why is that?
gd_8.applicant_turn: I didn't recognize the terminology in the moment. I understand guiding attention, but I didn't connect it to the phrase you used.

gd_9.interviewer_turn: You mentioned asking what font they like—what situations were you picturing when you said that?
gd_9.applicant_turn: Mostly small one-off pieces where the client has a strong preference. In other contexts it's driven by existing materials, but I gave an overly narrow example.

ml_0.interviewer_turn: You framed the goal as “a successfully working RAG system.” What success criteria or constraints were you implicitly assuming there?
ml_0.applicant_turn: I made it sound too simple. The stakeholder had specific constraints, but I didn't personally set them; I largely inherited the framing and focused on getting an end-to-end system working.

ml_1.interviewer_turn: You referred to “one bucket as the test bucket.” Why was the data bucketed like that in the first place?
ml_1.applicant_turn: To make clear which labeller was labelling which images. The test bucket was a random sample across all buckets (i.e. labelled samples) to ensure we got a representative mix of labeller opinions in the test set.

ml_2.interviewer_turn: You said accuracy was the most important thing—what exactly did you mean in that context?
ml_2.applicant_turn: I meant it was the metric we reported most often. I answered quickly and didn't mention other checks we did, so it came across like accuracy was the only thing that mattered.

ml_3.interviewer_turn: When you said you changed multiple hyperparameters at once—was that actually your standard approach?
ml_3.applicant_turn: That was early-stage exploration to get to a baseline fast. I shouldn't have implied it was a careful tuning strategy; it was a rough first pass.

ml_4.interviewer_turn: You described deployment as running it locally? What parts of the delivery story were missing from that summary?
ml_4.applicant_turn: So that was for during testing, we wanted to see how it would perform in the wild - that was not referring to the actual deployment.

ml_5.interviewer_turn: After the stakeholder meeting, you said you'd ask for the next dataset—why was this always your priority?
ml_5.applicant_turn: I was thinking of a specific case where data availability was the immediate blocker. It's not the only follow-up I'd do—I just named the first thing that came to mind.

ml_6.interviewer_turn: You said you “only” looked at accuracy—what did “only” mean there, exactly?
ml_6.applicant_turn: In that setup, accuracy was the main dashboard metric. I didn't list the other checks we discussed, so my wording overstated how narrow the evaluation really was.

ml_7.interviewer_turn: You mentioned unioning categories between train and test—what failure mode were you trying to prevent?
ml_7.applicant_turn: Category-mismatch errors at inference time. I glossed over the detail - we actually just used categories from the train set and excluded the few rows with different categories in the test set to at least avoid leakage.

ml_8.interviewer_turn: You said you randomly split across days—what assumption were you making when you chose that split?
ml_8.applicant_turn: That was a reflexive, generic answer. In that work the split was constrained by the data we had at the time, and I didn't mean to imply random splits are always appropriate for time series.

ml_9.interviewer_turn: You implied it was bad to make changes—what did you mean by this in practice?
ml_9.applicant_turn: I meant changes were risky and required coordination, not literally impossible. I used strong wording to convey fragility, not to claim it couldn't be improved at all.

sales_0.interviewer_turn: While focusing on the biggest names is sensible, did that mean you didn't look at smaller names?
sales_0.applicant_turn: Not at all, I meant to say that I started out with them, not that I neglected smaller names as they could often be more aligned customers.

sales_1.interviewer_turn: You described it as waiting for them to contact you—what does that actually mean in those situations?
sales_1.applicant_turn: There wasn't a formal follow-up channel because we met at a social event and people can find it intrusive if they think you are trying to 'sell' them something so I got better results by giving them my contact info and inviting them to contact me. However, I made sure to invite them to club events so I could organically engage with them again.

sales_2.interviewer_turn: You said you'd hand them a pamphlet—what was the interaction like beyond that headline?
sales_2.applicant_turn: That was the standard intro script for walk-ins when time was limited. I answered with the default short flow, not the fuller discovery process we'd use in a longer conversation.

sales_3.interviewer_turn: It sounds like you only mildly vary your core deck between clients? Have you considered tailoring them more?
sales_3.applicant_turn: It was a common starting deck. We'd adjust the content depending on the prospect, but I simplified the explanation instead of detailing the customization - we were often complemented on their specificity.

sales_4.interviewer_turn: You said you always talk to the most senior person—do you mean that literally?
sales_4.applicant_turn: No—that was an overstatement. I was describing where the final decision typically sits, not saying I never spoke with others in the process.

sales_5.interviewer_turn: When you said you try to convince them they need the product, how specifically would you do this?
sales_5.applicant_turn: I made it sound too blunt. I was trying to be quick and didn't describe how I first clarify what the objection actually is before responding.

sales_6.interviewer_turn: Why do you suspect that the finance rep often derailed prospective clients just before close?
sales_6.applicant_turn: I was giving an example of when we were trying to sell at the beginning of covid. Many clients reduced discretional spend and we were selling new tech - this wasn't a consequence of bad sales.

sales_7.interviewer_turn: How robust was your day-to-day note-taking system? Usually pipeline software is used.
sales_7.applicant_turn: Yes pipeline software is great, I meant to say I use my notepad as a scratch-space for thoughts because only my boss was allowed to make edits to the pipeline.

sales_8.interviewer_turn: It sounds like you mainly brute-forced your outreach?
sales_8.applicant_turn: Lead data quality was poor and segmentation fields weren't reliable, so the usual filters weren't workable. I was describing constraints, not claiming brute force is the best strategy.

sales_9.interviewer_turn: You said you cold-email “when you have time.” What cadence or pattern were you actually describing?
sales_9.applicant_turn: I meant it wasn't my full-time role and outreach happened opportunistically. It wasn't a deliberate outreach system; it was constrained by bandwidth. I had staff who performed outreach.
